items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  6.01
	 
	 
	 
	 
Educators such as teachers, technology specialists, counselors, and mentors play a pivotal role in addressing the shortage of young women in computing. The Aspirations Award identifies outstanding educators who play a pivotal role in helping to encourage the young women to continue exploring their interest in computing and technology. The NCWIT Aspirations in Computing Educator Award recognizes educators for their efforts to promote gender equity in computing.
	 
	 
The District congratulates Carol Ng as the recipient of the 2015 National Center for Women & Information Technology Aspirations in Computing Educator Award.

Item:  8.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cari Vaeth, Associate Superintendent of Human Resources
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and/or Discussion regarding Teach for America (TFA)
	 
	 
The District partners with Teach for America to provide nationwide recruitment and professional development of teacher candidates who are committed to closing the achievement gap in under-resourced school systems.  Fourteen corps members are currently teachers across our District.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.03
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Julie Kasberger, Director of Child Nutrition, and Jose Alvarado from Total School Solutions
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action regarding the Child Nutrition Services Program Review by Total School Solutions
	 
On February 12, 2015, the Board awarded a contract to Total School Solutions to conduct a Child Nutrition Services Program review (Board Item:19.01).  Total School Solutions conducted a review of specific components of the Child Nutrition Department; meal participation, cafeteria revenue, cafeteria expenses, analysis of financial standing, school site food service operations, staffing, organizational structure and menu planning.  They visited seven (7) sites to get a better understanding of the current program.  The Child Nutrition Services review is attached.  Jose Alvarado will present their process, findings and recommendations to the Board of Trustees. 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the Child Nutrition Services Program review.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Van T. Le, Board President
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve 5% Base Salary Increase to Superintendent Chris D. Funk, Associate Superintendents Marcus Battle, Juan Cruz and Cari Vaeth, and Senior Manager of Internal Controls Kelly Kwong Consistent with Bargaining Unit Salary Considerations Granted
	 
The District recently settled contract negotiations with ESTA, CSEA and AFT bargaining units, which resulted in a 5% on-schedule increase to the members of each of those bargaining units, retroactive to July 1, 2014.  
	 
In a previous agenda item, the Board is asked to consider and approve a 5% increase to management and staff not represented by a bargaining unit, also retroactive to July 1, 2014, i.e., consistent with the agreements reached with ESTA, CSEA and AFT.
	 
The contracts between the District and each of the Superintendent, the Associate Superintendent and the Senior Manager of Internal Controls provide that each of those person’s base salary “shall be increased prospectively by the same percentage salary increase that may be granted by the Board of Trustees” to the District’s certificated management or management personnel in any given school year.  (Emphasis added.)  Since the applicable agreements provide for only prospective application of base salary increases, the Board is asked to consider and approve the 5% increase in base salary to each of the Superintendent Chris D. Funk, Associate Superintendent Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent Cari Vaeth and Senior Manager of Internal Controls Kelly Kwong, plus any equivalent 2014-2015 increase given to the Certificated Management, effective July 1, 2014.  
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
As per the Superintendent, Associate Superintendent's  and Senior Manager of Internal Controls Contracts
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Various
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the 5% increase in base salary to each of the Superintendent Chris D. Funk, Associate Superintendent Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent Cari Vaeth and Senior Manager of Internal Controls Kelly Kwong, plus any equivalent 2014-2015 increase given to the Certificated Management, effective July 1, 2014.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the 5% increase in base salary to each of the Superintendent Chris D. Funk, Associate Superintendent Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent Cari Vaeth, and Senior Manager of Internal Controls Kelly Kwong, plus any equivalent 2014-2015 increase given to the Certificated Management, effective July 1, 2014.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  12.01
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services
						 
SUBJECT:
Receive the First Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaints Quarterly Report for Period Covering January 1, 2015,  through March 31, 2015, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727)
		 
BACKGROUND
As a result of the Williams Case (EC 35186), referred to as a landmark Superior Court case requires that every California public school provide each student with, at the very least, sufficient textbooks and instructional materials; clean, safe and functional buildings and facilities; and permanent, appropriately trained and assigned teachers.  Additionally, under the settlement of the Valenzuela / CAHSEE Settlement (EC 37254) students in grades 10 to 12 inclusive shall be notified of services available to students up to two consecutive years after the completion of grade 12 who have not yet passed the CAHSEE.
		 
School districts shall support summarized data on the nature and resolution of all Williams Complaints and Valenzuela / CAHSEE Complaints on a quarterly basis to the governing board and the county superintendent of schools.  The report shall include the number of complaints by general subject area with the number of resolved and unresolved complaints.
		 
The attached report indicates the number of complaints, if any, filed from January 1, 2015, through March 31, 2015. 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT
None
		 
FUNDING SOURCE
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
Other Categorical funds as Appropriate
		 
RECOMMENDATIONS
The administration recommends that the Governing Board accept the first Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint report for the period covering January 1, 2015, through March 31, 2015, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).
items.item_recommendation: The Administration recommends that the Governing Board accept the First Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint report for the period covering January 1, 2015, through March 31, 2015, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve the Service Increment Schedule for Classified Management
	 
	 
The District proposes to add years 24, 28 and 32 to the Classified Management  longevity service increment schedule.  All other  employee units earn longevity up to 32 years.  The current Classified Management service increments stop at the twentieth (20th) year.  The misalignment occurred after 2008 when some Directors were moved onto a Classified and Certificated Management salary schedule and Confidential employees longevity increments were aligned every four (4) years, up to the thirty-second (32nd) year.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$33,528.00
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the longevity service increment schedule up to 32 years for Classified Management.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Classified Management Job Description and Salary Range for Custodial Operations Supervisor
	 
	 
The Custodial Efficiency Study performed by Prismatic Services was shared with the Board of Trustees in January 2015. The final report came back with a particular finding (specifically 6.3), which noted, “the district lacks sufficient centralized coordination of its custodial staffs”.   The addition of a Custodial Operations Supervisor will provide centralized coordination, training and oversight to help standardize and improve custodial operations for the District’s 2.6 million square feet of learning environments. 
	 
The District is requesting the approval of the Classified Management job description and salary range for Custodial Operations Supervisor at a Range 16 with an annual salary of $62,484 - $81,528.  This is a 12 month Classified Management position. 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$62,484 - $81,528 / year
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund, Restricted Maintenance
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the classified management job description and salary range for Custodial Operations Supervisor.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  15.03
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Determine the Design Build Delivery for the Fire Alarm Upgrade Project will Reduce Project Costs, Expedite the Project's Completion or Provide Features Not Achievable Through the Design Bid Build Process
	 
On February 14, 2013, the Board considered public works construction project delivery methods, including design-bid-build, design-build, energy service contracting, and lease lease-back.  On June 11, 2013, the Board of Trustees authorized expenditure of Measure I funds for infrastructure projects.
	 
A Fire Alarm System Condition Study commissioned in 2014 found that fire alarm systems districtwide are in need of modernization.  The age and condition of the systems range from site to site.  Sites such as Calero and Overfelt Adult Center have systems whose panels, wiring and devices are newer.  Other sites have aged systems whose components are in fair to poor condition.  As individual buildings at those sites are modernized and new buildings constructed, current building codes mandate fire alarm system functionality that our existing systems do not have. The Study recommends replacement in whole or in part of site fire alarm systems, to support the demands of the modernization program code requirements, as well as mitigate the increasing annual repair and maintenance cost of the existing systems. 
	 
District and bond program management staff examined possible construction delivery methods, and have concluded that the use of design-build delivery for the project offers the following potential advantages to the District not available under a traditional design-bid-build delivery method:
	 
Simplified contracting and contract administration:  There is one contract with the design-build entity instead of separate contracts with an engineer and a contractor.   This reduces administrative burden and associated costs.
Cost containment:  The design-build entity is under a contract to complete the project meeting the District’s stated requirements within the contract price.
Cost savings:  Innovative, cost-effective solutions meeting performance criteria can be achieved by collaboration between the designer and builder, adding construction practicality to design imagination.  The builder is involved in the design process from the beginning and can provide helpful insights on construction materials and methods that can make the design more efficient and less costly to construct, operate and maintain. 
Early cost definition:  Project costs are determined much sooner than with the traditional design-bid-build process.   The design-build method enables the District to determine the cost of the project upon award of the design-build contract instead of after Division of the State Engineer approval and construction contract bidding.   This early cost knowledge allows the District to make informed decisions on detailed scope in order to ensure equity of outcomes among the school sites.
Reduced number of change orders and disputes:  Because the designer and builder are part of the same design-build entity, and the District is not the guarantor of the completeness and accuracy of the work of the engineer, the District may avoid conflicts and disputes, and the corresponding costs of those conflicts and disputes that can arise between the engineer and construction contractor.
Greater risk shifting and more efficient risk allocation:  The vesting of design and construction functions under one entity enables proper allocation of risk under the design-build contract, because the contractor’s involvement in constructability review and existing site condition surveys during preconstruction activities reduces or eliminates the need for redesign during the construction phase. 
Reduction in adversarial relationships:  The designer and builder are teamed together, working under a single contract.  This teaming can significantly reduce traditional conflicts and finger-pointing between designer and contractor, and eliminate the need for the District to referee disputes.
Time savings:  The design-build entity is allowed the freedom to explore time-saving construction methods or systems while meeting the District’s stated criteria.  Early coordination between the designer and builder can help prevent construction delays.   Additionally, by overlapping design and construction to some extent, design-build can deliver the project faster than the design-bid-build approach.  Any and all of these elements can accelerate delivery of modernized fire alarm systems.
Alternative selection process: Design-build entities may be selected on the basis of factors other than price alone.  Design-build entities can assemble a team of engineers, architects, subcontractors and suppliers with whom they have had previous successful collaborations, and that reflect the goals and needs of the project.  The District can select the winning team based on not only price, but also other factors including technical expertise, life cycle cost over 15 years or more, skilled labor force availability, safety record, successful previous experience, project-specific plans and schedules, design, and other qualitative elements.
	 
Education Code §17250.20 stipulates that upon making a determination by the governing board that it is in the best interest of the District, the Board may enter into a design-build contract for both the design and construction of a school facility if that expenditure exceeds two million five hundred thousand dollars ($2,500,000) if, after evaluation of the traditional design, bid, and build process of school construction and of the design-build process in a public meeting, the governing board makes written findings that use of the design-build process on the specific project under consideration will accomplish one of the following objectives:  reduce comparable project costs, expedite the project's completion, or provide features not achievable through the traditional design-bid-build method.  The governing board also shall review the guidelines developed pursuant to Education Code §17250.40 (Attachment A) and shall adopt a resolution approving the use of a design-build contract pursuant to this chapter prior to entering into a design-build contract.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees, having reviewed the guidelines developed pursuant to Education Code §17250.40, approve the determination that design-build delivery for the Districtwide Fire Alarm Modernization Project will reduce project costs, expedite the project’s completion, or provide features not achievable through the design-bid-build process.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees, having reviewed the guidelines developed pursuant to Education Code §17250.40, approve the determination that design-build delivery for the Districtwide Fire Alarm Modernization Project will reduce project costs, expedite the project’s completion, or provide features not achievable through the design-bid-build process.

SUBJECT:
Approve California Interscholastic Federation (CIF) Application for Renewal of 2015-2016 Multi-School Membership
	 
	 
Pursuant to California Interscholastic Federation regulations, CIF-member schools may allow only students currently enrolled, in grades 9-12, in their school, to participate in any CIF competition.  Any CIF-member school that wishes to allow participation on its team(s) by students, who are currently enrolled in non-CIF-member schools or programs which do not offer any interscholastic athletic programs (i.e. small but necessary schools), may request approval to do so.
	 
The administrative responsibility for all students involved in athletics shall rest with the Principal of the CIF-member school for which the student(s) is competing.  Students must meet all the CIF-member scholastic eligibility requirements.

$14,549.85
